content.heading: Frequently asked
content.description: Have questions? We have answers.

faqs.question: Can I change my plan later?
faqs.answer: Yes, you can upgrade or downgrade your plan at any time. Changes take effect immediately, and we'll prorate your billing.

faqs.question: What payment methods do you accept?
faqs.answer: We accept all major credit cards (Visa, MasterCard, American Express), PayPal, and bank transfers for annual plans.

faqs.question: Is there a free trial?
faqs.answer: Yes! All paid plans include a 14-day free trial. No credit card required to start.

faqs.question: What happens when my trial ends?
faqs.answer: At the end of your trial, you can choose to subscribe to a paid plan or continue with our free Starter plan.

content.heading: Privacy

content.summaryContent: We respect your privacy and only collect data necessary to provide our services. We never sell your data.

sections.title: Information We Collect
sections.content: We collect information you provide directly to us, such as when you create an account, make a purchase, or contact us for support.

sections.title: How We Use Your Information
sections.content: We use the information we collect to provide, maintain, and improve our services, process transactions, and communicate with you.

sections.title: Information Sharing
sections.content: We do not sell, trade, or rent your personal information to third parties. We may share information with service providers who assist us in operating our platform.

sections.title: Data Security
sections.content: We implement appropriate security measures to protect your personal information against unauthorized access, alteration, disclosure, or destruction.

sections.title: Your Rights
sections.content: You have the right to access, update, or delete your personal information at any time. Contact us to exercise these rights.

content.footerText: This policy is part of our

content.heading: Terms of
content.description: Please read these terms carefully before using our services.
content.summaryContent: Use our services responsibly. We provide them as-is and reserve the right to modify or terminate them.

sections.title: Acceptance of Terms
sections.content: By accessing or using our services, you agree to be bound by these Terms of Service and all applicable laws and regulations.

sections.title: Use of Services
sections.content: You may use our services only for lawful purposes and in accordance with these Terms. You agree not to use our services in any way that violates any applicable law or regulation.

sections.title: User Accounts
sections.content: You are responsible for maintaining the confidentiality of your account credentials and for all activities that occur under your account.

sections.title: Intellectual Property
sections.content: The content, features, and functionality of our services are owned by us and are protected by international copyright, trademark, and other intellectual property laws.

sections.title: Limitation of Liability

metadata.title: Terms of Service
metadata.description: Terms and conditions for using our services.

content.heading: Cookie
content.description: This policy explains how we use cookies and similar technologies.
content.summaryContent: We use essential cookies to make our site work and analytics cookies to understand how you use it. You can control your preferences.

sections.title: What Are Cookies
sections.content: Cookies are small text files that are placed on your device when you visit a website. They help the website remember your preferences and improve your experience.

sections.title: How We Use Cookies
sections.content: We use cookies to keep you signed in, remember your preferences, understand how you use our site, and improve our services.

sections.title: Types of Cookies We Use
sections.content:
Essential cookies: Required for the site to function properly.
Analytics cookies: Help us understand how visitors interact with our site.
Preference cookies: Remember your settings and preferences.

sections.title: Managing Cookies
sections.content: Most browsers allow you to control cookies through their settings. However, disabling certain cookies may affect your experience on our site.

content.footerText: This policy is part of our

metadata.title: Cookie Policy
metadata.description: Information about how we use cookies on our website.

metadata.title: Documentation

content.title: Installation
content.description: Get up and running with cmssy in under 5 minutes.
content.content:
Prerequisites

Before you begin, make sure you have the following installed on your machine:

  • Node.js 18+ — we recommend using nvm to manage versions
  • pnpm — our recommended package manager (npm and yarn also work)
  • Git — for version control and publishing

Install the CLI

Install the cmssy CLI globally to access all commands from your terminal:

Create a Project

Scaffold a new project with the init command. This creates the directory structure, installs dependencies, and sets up Tailwind CSS:

Configure API Access

Connect your project to the cmssy platform by running the configure command. You'll need your workspace API token from the dashboard:

Start Development

Launch the development server with hot-reload and live preview:

Open http://localhost:3000 to see the dev UI. You'll see a list of all blocks in your project with a live preview and content editor.

Next Steps

Now that you're set up, explore the following guides:

  • Quickstart — build and publish your first block
  • Blocks — understand block anatomy and schemas
  • Templates — compose blocks into full-page templates

content.code:
npm install -g cmssy-cli

# or with pnpm
pnpm add -g cmssy-cli

# Verify installation
cmssy --version

content.title: Using npx
content.content: You can also use npx cmssy-cli without installing globally. This is useful for CI/CD pipelines or one-off commands.

metadata.title: Installation — cmssy Docs
metadata.description: Install the CLI and set up your first project.

content.title: Quickstart
content.description: Build and publish your first block in 5 minutes.
content.content:
Create a Block

Use the create command to scaffold a new block. This generates the component, styles, schema, and preview data:

This creates the following structure:

Define the Schema

Open block.config.ts to define the content schema. The schema determines what fields appear in the CMS editor:

Build the Component

Edit src/MyBlock.tsx to build your UI. The component receives a content prop with all schema fields:

Preview Locally

Run cmssy dev and select your block from the sidebar. The preview updates in real-time as you edit the code. Use the editor panel on the right to modify content fields.

Publish

When you're happy with your block, publish it to the platform:

Your block is now available in the CMS for any page in your workspace.

content.code:
cmssy create my-block

# With options
cmssy create hero-banner --category marketing

content.title: Hot Reload
content.content: The dev server watches for file changes and updates the preview instantly. CSS changes via Tailwind are also picked up automatically — no restart needed.

metadata.title: Quickstart — cmssy Docs
metadata.description: Build and publish your first block.

content.title: Blocks
content.description: Blocks are the fundamental building units of your site. Each block is a self-contained React component with a content schema.
content.content:
What is a Block?

A block is a reusable UI component that can be placed on any page. Each block consists of:

  • Component (src/index.tsx) — the React component that renders the UI
  • Schema (block.config.ts) — defines the content fields and their types
  • Styles (src/index.css) — component-specific CSS (Tailwind classes work out of the box)
  • Preview data (preview.json) — sample content for the dev preview

Block Anatomy

Every block follows the same directory structure:

Schema Field Types

The schema defines what content editors can configure. Available field types:

  • singleLine — short text input
  • multiLine — textarea for longer content
  • richText — HTML content with formatting
  • boolean — toggle switch
  • select — dropdown with predefined options
  • media — image/file upload
  • link — URL input
  • repeater — list of nested fields (arrays)
  • numeric — number input with min/max
  • date — date picker
  • color — color picker

Conditional Fields

Use showWhen to conditionally show fields based on other field values. This keeps the editor clean by hiding irrelevant options:

Layout Positions

Blocks can declare a layoutPosition to indicate they belong in a specific area of the page layout:

  • header — rendered at the top of every page
  • footer — rendered at the bottom of every page
  • sidebar_left — rendered as a left sidebar

Layout blocks are shared across all pages in a template and configured once in pages.json under layoutPositions.

content.code:
blocks/my-block/
├── block.config.ts    # Schema + metadata
├── package.json       # Dependencies
├── preview.json       # Sample content
└── src/
    ├── index.tsx       # Entry point (re-export)
    ├── index.css       # Styles
    ├── MyBlock.tsx     # Component
    └── block.d.ts      # TypeScript types

content.title: Block Type Names
content.content: Block types use the format @scope/blocks.block-name. The scope comes from your package.json name field. When referencing blocks in pages.json, always use the full qualified name.

metadata.title: Blocks — cmssy Docs
metadata.description: Learn how blocks work and how to create your own.

content.title: Templates
content.description: Templates are collections of pages that compose blocks into complete websites. They're pure manifests — no component code, just configuration.
content.content:
What is a Template?

A template defines a multi-page site by combining blocks with content. Unlike blocks, templates have no React component. They consist of:

  • pages.json — defines all pages, their blocks, and content
  • block.config.ts — template metadata and global settings schema
  • package.json — dependencies and template info

pages.json Structure

The pages.json file is the heart of a template. It defines layout positions (header, footer) and individual pages with their blocks:

Layout Positions

Layout positions are blocks that appear on every page. The most common are:

  • header — site navigation, rendered at the top
  • footer — site footer, rendered at the bottom
  • sidebar_left — documentation sidebar

Each layout position specifies a block type and its content. This content is shared across all pages.

Publishing Templates

When you publish a template, the CLI:

  1. Publishes all referenced blocks that have changed
  2. Creates or updates all pages defined in pages.json
  3. Sets up layout positions (header, footer)

Templates don't have source code to compile — they're pure configuration. This makes publishing fast and reliable.

Dev Preview

Run cmssy dev and click on a template to see a full composed preview. The dev server renders all blocks on each page with a navigation bar to switch between pages. Use Ctrl+K to quickly jump to any page.

content.title: Template vs Block
content.content: Think of blocks as components and templates as compositions. Blocks are the bricks, templates are the blueprints. You develop blocks individually, then assemble them into templates.

metadata.title: Templates — cmssy Docs
metadata.description: Compose blocks into complete multi-page sites.

content.title: Theming
content.description: Customize the look and feel of your site using CSS variables and Tailwind CSS v4.
content.content:
Color System

Cmssy uses OKLCH color values defined as CSS variables. The theme is split into semantic tokens that adapt to light and dark modes:

  • --background / --foreground — page background and text
  • --primary / --primary-foreground — primary action buttons
  • --muted / --muted-foreground — subtle backgrounds and helper text
  • --card / --card-foreground — card surfaces
  • --border — default border color
  • --destructive — error and danger states

Customizing Colors

Edit the :root block in styles/main.css to change your color palette. Use OKLCH values for perceptual uniformity:

Dark Mode

Dark mode is controlled by the .dark class on the root element. Override the same variables in the .dark selector:

Tailwind CSS v4

The project uses Tailwind CSS v4 with CSS-first configuration. Key differences from v3:

  • No tailwind.config.js — everything lives in CSS
  • @theme inline maps CSS variables to Tailwind utilities
  • @source directives tell Tailwind which files to scan for class names
  • Gradient classes use bg-linear-to-r instead of bg-gradient-to-r
  • Shadow scale shifted: shadow-sm in v4 = old bare shadow

Border Radius

Border radius uses a base --radius variable. All radius tokens are derived from it:

  • rounded-sm = calc(var(--radius) - 4px)
  • rounded-md = calc(var(--radius) - 2px)
  • rounded-lg = var(--radius) (10px default)
  • rounded-xl = calc(var(--radius) + 4px)

content.title: OKLCH Colors
content.content: OKLCH provides perceptually uniform colors — two colors with the same lightness value actually look equally bright. Use the OKLCH color picker to find values. Format: oklch(lightness chroma hue).

content.title: Tailwind v4 Class Changes
content.content: If you're coming from Tailwind v3, watch out for renamed utilities: shadow-sm → shadow-xs, rounded-sm → rounded-xs, outline-none → outline-hidden, bg-gradient-* → bg-linear-*. The scale shifted down by one step.
